entry.title: Development of Cognitive Operations (Piaget)
entry.summary:
Development of Cognitive Operations (Piaget)

Add

gantt
dateFormat YY-MM …
entry.content:
Development of Cognitive Operations (Piaget)

Add
- [ ] conservation failure/emergence - [ ] types of conservation - [ ] classification failure/emergence - [ ] transductive reasoning (until age 7) - [ ] conservation failure/emergence - [ ] varieties and order them (substance precedes volume & weight) - [ ] egocentrism (diminishes by age 8) - [ ] centration/decentration - [ ] perseveration - [ ] animism (ends age 3) - [ ] inductive reasoning - [ ] irreversibility/reversibility

gantt
dateFormat YY-MM
axisFormat %y%m
tickInterval 6month
todayMarker off

section sensorimotor (0-2 yrs.)
substage 1 (reflexes - sucking, gaze, palmer grasp) : 00-01, 1M
substage 2 (primary circular reactions - repetitive actions w/ self) : 3M
substage 3 (secondary circular reactions - repetitive actions w/ objects) : 4M
substage 4 (coordination of secondary circular reactions) : 4M
substage 5 (tertiary circular reactions - experimentation) : 6M
substage 6 (transition) : 6M
beginning representational thought : 02-01
intentional grasping : milestone, 00-02, 0d
object permanence : milestone, 00-08, 0d
trial-and-error, causality : milestone, 01-01, 0d

section preoperational (2-7 yrs.)
symbolic function substage (perception) : 02-01, 2y
intuitve thought substage : 3y
language : 02-01, 5y
pretend play : 02-01, 5y

section formal operational (7-11 yrs.)

Theory

entry.title: operation (Piaget)
entry.content:
operation (Piaget)

operation
logical manipulation of information

#Term

entry.title: transductive reasoning (Piaget)
entry.summary:
transductive reasoning (Piaget)

transductive reasoning
making faulty inferences from one specific example to another

Examples

Lucienne Piaget: "It's not afternoon because I haven't had my nap yet!"

Piaget: "Are there more daisies or flowers?"
Subject (age 7): "More daisies."

Notes & Links

  • overgeneralization
    • see "Cognitive Development in Children" for 'generalization'
  • Development …

entry.title: accommodation (Piaget)
entry.content:
accommodation (Piaget)

accommodation
the restructuring of old ideas to include new experiences
construction of new logical operations
inverse of assimilation (Piaget)

Term

entry.title: assimilation (Piaget)
entry.content:
assimilation (Piaget)

assimilation
reinterpretation of new experiences to fit into old ideas
integrating stimuli into extant knowledge structures
inverse of accommodation (Piaget)

#Term

entry.title: classification (Piaget)
entry.summary:
classification (Piaget)

classification
the logical operation that things can be organized into groups or categories or classes according to some common characteristic [^1]
typically acquired by 8 yrs., during the concrete operational stage [^1]: Piaget references the "daisy vs. flower" example to illustrate how understanding of nested hierarchies is developed …

classification

typically acquired by 8 yrs., during the concrete operational stage [^1]: Piaget references the "daisy vs. flower" example to illustrate how understanding of nested hierarchies is developed "Cognitive Development in Children"

entry.title: "Cognitive Development in Children"
entry.summary:
"Cognitive Development in Children"

- distinguishes between "the problem of development in general and the problem of learning" (p. 176) - development of knowledge is tied to embryogenesis - spontaneous, emergent, innate - development of leaning is adaptive

  • on operations:

    "To understand the development of knowledge, we must start with an idea which is …
entry.content:
"Cognitive Development in Children"

- distinguishes between "the problem of development in general and the problem of learning" (p. 176) - development of knowledge is tied to embryogenesis - spontaneous, emergent, innate - development of leaning is adaptive

  • on operations:

    "To understand the development of knowledge, we must start with an idea which is central to-the idea of an operation. Knowledge is not a copy of reality. To know an object, to know an event, is not sirnply to look at it and make a inental copy or image of it. To know an object is to act on it. To know is to modify, to transform the object, and to understand the process of this transformation, and as a consequence to understand the way the object is constructed. An operation is thus the essence of knowledge; it is an interiorized action which modifies the object of knowledge...in addition, it is a reversible action; that is, it can take place in both directions, for instance, adding or subtracting, joining or separating...Above all, an operation is never isolated. It is always linked to other operations, and as a result it is always a part of a total structure."

(p. 176-177)

  • outlines cognitive stages briefly
    1. sensorimotor stage
      • 0-18 mos. (1.5 yrs.)
      • practical knowledge is developed, substructures which serve as precursors to representational knowledge
        • object permanence
        • practical space
        • temporal succession
    2. preoperational stage
      • representational thought is developed, substructures which serve as precursors to operations
        • symbolic function conservation is not yet developed, precluding reversible operations
    3. concrete operational stage
      • first operations are developed but are only conducted on objects - classification - ordering - number - spatial - temporal - elementary logic, mathematics, geometry, physics
  • formal operational stage - development of hypothetic-deuctive operations - may construct new operations - propositional logic - combinatorial structures - complicated group structures - builds on concrete operations - classification by successive inclusions
  • four factors facilitating development of knowledge (i.e., acquisition of structures)
    1. maturation
      • development of knowledge cannot be entirely attributed to the interior changes of the nervous system
      • the chronological ages at which the operational stages develop vary cross-culturally although the sequence is preservered
    2. experience
      • practice navigating the physical world is also not enough to explain development of knowledge
        • at 8yrs., a child begins to conserve
          • first exhibits conservation of substance, then weight, then volume horizontal decalage (Piaget)
            • conservation of substance (amount) is exhibited although it cannot be learned from experience and despite lacking conservation of weight and volume
      • distinguishes two kinds of experience
      • practical (pertains to learning properties of objects)
      • logical-mathematical (pertains to learning properties of actions)
    3. social transmission
      1. linguistic or educational
        1. insufficient for provoking knowledge if a child lacks the capacity for symbolic function which is need to receive this information
    4. equilibration cognitive equilibrium (Piaget)
      1. reflected by displaying compensation, a critical cognitive factor that enables operational reversibility
        1. understanding an object that is transformed in one direction is necessarily also transformed in the other direction
        2. resolution of inconsistencies, imbalance, dissonance; absence of confusion
  • on equilibration and information-processing theory:

    “Equilibration, as I understand it, is thus an active process. It is a process of self-regulation. I think that this self-regulation is a fundamental factor in development. I use this term in the sense in which it is used in cybernetics, that is, in the sense of processes with feedback and with feedforward, of processes which regulate theniselves by a progressive compensation of systems. ”

(p.181)

  • rejects the stimulus-response schema of cognition as the response precedes the stimulus
    • unless the subject possesses a structure that may receive and integrate the signal, an object cannot be a stimulus
      • follows from the view of development of knowledge as emergent
  • illustrates with example of colleague's study of children acquiring conservation of weight vs. transitivity of weight
    • succesfully reinforced the former as it can be learned through practical experience
    • failed to reinforce the latter as logical-mathematical experience cannot be transmitted in this fashion, unless the prequisite structures are available
    • thus, no correlation between experimenter reinforcement and subject knowledge of transitivity
      • the opposite for conservation
        • however conservation of number can be learned, that is, its acquisition can be accelerated after 4 yrs.
          • at 5-5.5 yrs. children can generalize for objects outside of perception if trained using their own actions via additive operations
            • capable of recursive reasoning
  • relationship between stimulus and response is not merely one of association but of, fundamentally, assimilation assimilation (Piaget)

    Assimilation is not the same as association. I shall define assimilation as the integration of any sort of reality into a structure, and it is this assimilation which seems to me to be fundamental in learning, and which seems to me to be the fundamental relation from the point of view of pedagogical or didactic applications.

(p. 185)

  • emphasizes that learning is an active process
  • draws connection to Hull's theories
    • transformation responses = operations
    • internal reinforcements = equilibration

entry.title: cognitive equilibrium (Piaget)
entry.content:
cognitive equilibrium (Piaget)

Term

cognitive equilibrium
in cognitive theory, a state of mental balance in which people are not confused because they can use their existing thought processes to understand current experiences and ideas

"Cognitive Development in Children"

entry.title: cognitive theory
entry.content:
cognitive theory

Term

cognitive theory
a grand theory of human development that focuses on changes in how people think over time
according to this theory, our thoughts shape our attitudes, beliefs and behaviours

Word

educable
capable of being educated

entry.title: horizontal decalage (Piaget)
entry.summary:
horizontal decalage (Piaget)

Term

horizontal decalage
the idea that at each level certain concepts appear in sequence over months or even years
stages of knowledge development are sequential and discrete[^1]

[^1]: the acquisition of conservation of weight and volume build on the conservation of substance "Cognitive Development in Children …
entry.content:
horizontal decalage (Piaget)

Term

horizontal decalage
the idea that at each level certain concepts appear in sequence over months or even years
stages of knowledge development are sequential and discrete[^1]

[^1]: the acquisition of conservation of weight and volume build on the conservation of substance "Cognitive Development in Children"

entry.title: Hulling
entry.summary:
Hulling

For a hundred years I had lain
in the bedrock
heavy, penitent, waiting.
This stone could not be wrought.
Turn it to silt, scattering in water and wind.
Till then, let me be
numb, untouched.

Then, springtime comes, looks on me and there have been a thousand springtimes. Still …
entry.content:
Hulling

For a hundred years I had lain
in the bedrock
heavy, penitent, waiting.
This stone could not be wrought.
Turn it to silt, scattering in water and wind.
Till then, let me be
numb, untouched.

Then, springtime comes, looks on me and there have been a thousand springtimes. Still, a warm ray is flickering on my face and I — Don't dare tend to it. But something is stirring. Betraying change.

entry.title: information-processing theory
entry.summary:
information-processing theory

Term

information processing theory
a perspective that figures human cognition as analogous to computational analysis of data, consisting of sensory input, connections, memory storage, and ouput
emphasizes processes of thought in contrast to the Piagetian focus on responses ^[1]

[^1]: but Piaget also offered a theory that is …
entry.content:
information-processing theory

Term

information processing theory
a perspective that figures human cognition as analogous to computational analysis of data, consisting of sensory input, connections, memory storage, and ouput
emphasizes processes of thought in contrast to the Piagetian focus on responses ^[1]

[^1]: but Piaget also offered a theory that is considered to push back against stimulus-response views of cognition and moreover, also referenced cybernetics as an analogy for reinforcement learning "Cognitive Development in Children"

entry.title: seriation (Piaget)
entry.content:
seriation (Piaget)

#Term
seriation
the concept that things can be arranged in a logical series, such as the number sequence or the alphabet
critical for mathematics

entry.content:
You Will Never Graduate Lmao

Index

PSY-SPEC Program Requirements

[=8/25 "8/25"]

  • 12.5 CR (25 courses)
    • 3.0 CR (6 courses) C/D-level
    • 1.0 CR (2 courses) D-level

Introduction to Pyschology (1 CR, 2 courses)

  • PSYA01*
  • PSYA02*

[=2/25 "Total: 2/25"]

Laboratory Methods(1.5 CR, 3 courses)

  • PSYB70*
  • PSYC70*
  • PSYC75 → IPR

[=4/25 "Total: 4/25"]

Statistical Methods (1 CR, 2 courses)

  • PSYB07*
  • PSYC08

[=8/25 "Total: 8/25"]

Scientific Communication (0.5 CR, 1 course)

  • PSYC02* → IPR

History of Psychology (0.5 CR, 1 course)

  • PSYC85* → IPR

Social/Developmental B/C-level (2 CR, 4 courses)

Perception/Cognition/Physiology B/C-level (2 CR, 4 courses)

Social/Developmental Seminar D-level (0.5 CR, 1 course)

Perception/Cognition/Physiology D-level (0.5 CR, 1 course)

Additional B/C/D-level (2 CR, 4 courses)

Additional C-level (1 CR, 2 courses)

Thesis Course (½) (0.5 CR, 1 course) - [x] PSYD98

entry.title: Interpersonal Relationships Paper
entry.summary:
Interpersonal Relationships Paper: The Female Dating Strategy

  • Paper should be critiquing pop psych dating advice
  • FDS is an interesting angle because we're inundated with redpill/manosphere content (in psych too, lots of papers about incels) but their distaff counterparts are understudied
  • the official FDS blog uses psych in their articles …
entry.content:
Interpersonal Relationships Paper: The Female Dating Strategy

  • Paper should be critiquing pop psych dating advice
  • FDS is an interesting angle because we're inundated with redpill/manosphere content (in psych too, lots of papers about incels) but their distaff counterparts are understudied
  • the official FDS blog uses psych in their articles
  • vetting strats?
    • probably stereotypes about men to avoid on dating apps & rationale
    • cohabitation
      • on SES
      • FDS is anti-cohabitation because it allows men to defer their proposals ("why buy the cow when you can get the milk for free?")

entry.content:
Middle Childhood Midterm

Fleeting

  • relationship between exercise and brain goes both ways
    • cognitive upgrades
    • embodied cognition
      • selective attention
      • RT
  • childhood obesity
    • 95th percentile
  • childhood overweight
    • 85th percentile
  • social exclusion is an issue
  • what is asthma
  • obesity and asthma lead to social exclusion
  • obesity and parenting
  • obesity rates rise if
    • formula and solid foods before 4 mos .
    • tv in bedroom and drink soda by preschool (early childhood)
    • middle childhood lack sleep, watch screens, don't play outside
  • pester power: the ability to get adults to do what they want
    • fewer kids = |^ pester power
  • boring stats about obesity
    • causes more deaths than malnutrtion
  • hygiene hypothesis: children are overprotected from viruses and bacteria, weakened immune system
    • more common in first-borns, C-section babies less common on the farm
    • link to allergies?
    • words
      • remediate
      • senescence
    • define
      • developmental psychopathology
      • comorbid
      • childhood obesity vs. childhood overweight
      • pester power
      • embodied cognition
      • selective attention
      • reaction time
      • developmental psychopathology
    • which kids will likely develop asthma?
      • which kids will likely develop allergies
        • hygiene hypothesis
    • physical health and social exclusion in middle childhood
      • obesity
      • isolation
      • asthma
  • four principles of developmental psychopathology
    1. abnormal is normal, normal is abnormal
      1. not everyone is neurodivergent. most people are just weird
    2. disabilities change
    3. prognosis is uncertain
    4. diagnosis and treatment of psychopathology are dependent on societal context (macro or micro? look up that guy brofenbrenner baum ferger or wtv)
  • define:
    • aptitude: potential to master a specific skill or learn a certain body of knowledge
    • intelligence the ability to learn and understand various aspects of life; conventionally referring to reading and math, increasingly arts, movement, and social interactions
  • OG IQ formula:
    • mental age/chronological age * 100
      • mental age: mean age associated with a particular test score
  • define:
    • achievement test
      • how is it different from an aptitude test?
  • achievement vs. aptitude
  • define:
    • the flynn effect
    • more apparent for women
    • g: is calculated based on the average mental age of people of a particular chronological age.
  • IQ
    • vocabulary is critical :)
    • for g: speed & memory are crucial
  • intelligence can grow
    • neuroplasticity link
  • theory: multiple intelligences
    • Robert Sternberg and Howard Gardner
    • sternberg:
      • analytic
      • creative
      • practical (didn't aristotle have that with pragmatic intelligence?)
      • may not be academic achievers but fluorish later
      • theory: seven multiple intelligences (Gardner)
        • verbal-linguistic
        • logical-mathematical,
        • musical
        • intrapersonal
        • interpersonal
        • bodily-kinesthetic
        • spatial
        • plus 2
          • naturalistic
          • spiritiual
  • achievement does not reflect aptitude; cultural bieases
  • brain scans
    • do not correlation w/ IQ in childhood (maye we just dont know how to look) ut they do later on
    • can measure RT (link to RT) which → adult IQ
    • less brain activity ≠ less intelligence
      • opposite might be true
      • maybe treatmant resistance
    • sMRI
      • thicker cortex sometimes correlated with high IQ
        • but in 9-11-yr-olds, high vocabulary related to thinner cortex and vocab is part of g and academic achievement

Note Clusters

  • Intelligence
    • Intelligence
      • Flynn Effect
        • Women
    • Aptitude vs. Achievement
    • Measuring Intelligence: Calculating IQ & g
      • Vocabulary
      • Speed & Memory
    • Multiple Intelligences
      • Howard Gardner - 7
      • Robert Sternberg - 3
        • Aristotle
  • Executive Functions
    • Reaction Time
    • Executive Functions
      • Selective Attention
      • Delayed Gratification
      • Emotional Regulation
      • Motivation
  • Parenting
  • Physical Health and Brain Development
    • BMI
    • Obesity
    • Asthma
      • Hygiene Hypothesis
        • Allergies
  • Developmental Psychopathology
    • Four Principles
      • Comorbidity
  • Statistics
  • Remediate
  • Senesence
  • Physical Development Milestones
  • Development of Motor Skills
